coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode with promoted charge separation for photoelectrochemical sewage treatment to simultaneously degrade PPCPs, disinfect E. coli, and produce H2: Performance, mechanisms, and influence factors
coredata.dc:creator: Zheng, Zexiao
Lo, Irene M.C.
coredata.dc:description:
Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) and Escherichia coli (E. coli) are ubiquitous in sewage posing adverse effects on both ecosystems and human health. Herein, we propose a multifunctional photoelectrochemical (PEC) system to simultaneously degrade PPCPs, disinfect E. coli, and produce H2. To this end, an optimized MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode with reduced bulk and surface charge recombination was synthesized, exhibiting a photocurrent density of 2.21 mA/cm2 at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl in actual sewage, 8.1 times that of P-BiVO4. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode achieved complete degradation of 2 ppm benzophenone-3 and inactivation of E. coli in sewage with 89.32 μmol H2 evolution at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl in 30 min. Chloride ions in the sewage played a critical role in the PEC system: they were activated to become chloride-based radicals (
Cl,
ClO) for sewage treatment and worked as hole scavengers to increase H2 evolution. Natural organic matters in the sewage played a dominant role in impeding the PEC reactions because they can quench the reactive species and were adsorbed onto the photoanode’s surface to block charge separation. The PEC system shows good efficiency when degrading various PPCPs, and excellent reusability and stability, giving it great practicality.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) and Escherichia coli (E. coli) are ubiquitous in sewage posing adverse effects on both ecosystems and human health. Herein, we propose a multifunctional photoelectrochemical (PEC) system to simultaneously degrade PPCPs, disinfect E. coli, and produce H2. To this end, an optimized MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode with reduced bulk and surface charge recombination was synthesized, exhibiting a photocurrent density of 2.21 mA/cm2 at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl in actual sewage, 8.1 times that of P-BiVO4. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode achieved complete degradation of 2 ppm benzophenone-3 and inactivation of E. coli in sewage with 89.32 μmol H2 evolution at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl in 30 min. Chloride ions in the sewage played a critical role in the PEC system: they were activated to become chloride-based radicals (
Cl,
ClO) for sewage treatment and worked as hole scavengers to increase H2 evolution. Natural organic matters in the sewage played a dominant role in impeding the PEC reactions because they can quench the reactive species and were adsorbed onto the photoanode’s surface to block charge separation. The PEC system shows good efficiency when degrading various PPCPs, and excellent reusability and stability, giving it great practicality.

ce:section.ce:para:
Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs), a group of recalcitrant organic pollutants, are widely used in daily life. They are discharged into sewage treatment plants via using makeup, detergents, skin protectors, ingesting pharmaceuticals, etc. PPCPs pose significant threats to ecosystems and living organisms because there has not been any efficient way to remove them in conventional wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) [1,2]. In addition, Escherichia coli (E. coli), which mainly comes from the excrement, is a critical microorganism pathogen in sewage, posing adverse effects on humans and animals [3]. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) have recently been developed and integrated into sewage treatment plants to degrade micro-pollutants and inactivate pathogenic microorganisms [4,5]. In typical AOPs, strongly-oxidizing species such as reactive chlorine species (
Cl,
ClO), sulfate radicals (
SO4 −), and hydroxyl radicals (
OH) are generated to remove micro-pollutants and pathogenic microorganisms rapidly [6–8].

The photocatalytic-assisted AOPs offer promising technology for sewage treatment because they consume little energy and produce a significant amount of active species, exhibiting high efficiency in micro-pollutant degradation and pathogen disinfection [9–13]. However, their practicality is still held back by several limitations: (1) high charge recombination rate in the photocatalytic system lowers wastewater treatment efficiency, and suspension-type photocatalysts may cause severe secondary pollution; (2) specific chemicals such as HClO, KHSO5, H2O2 need to be added to initiate the chemical reactions, increasing costs for sewage treatment [6–8]; (3) and no high-value product except the treated sewage can be produced to offset sewage treatment cost. Moreover, most previous studies were conducted in simulated wastewater, which cannot prove the practicability in actual sewage.

To address these limitations, a multifunctional photoelectrochemical (PEC) system was developed to simultaneously degrade PPCPs, disinfect E. coli, and produce H2 in real sewage: (1) Developed from photocatalysis, the PEC process applies a low voltage across photoelectrodes where photocatalysts are anchored, thereby improving the treatment efficiency via reducing charge recombination, as well as eliminating secondary pollution [14,15]. (2) Chloride ions (Cl−) are ubiquitous in various water bodies (Table S1), which can be activated in-situ to produce chloride-based radicals for sewage treatment to remove the cost of adding chemicals [16]. In the PEC system, Cl− can be activated by photogenerated holes (h+) to produce
Cl (∼2.4 eV) and
ClO (∼1.8 eV), which are strong oxidants for accelerating the sewage treatment process [17]. (3) In a conventional PEC process for sewage treatment, the degradation of pollutants and disinfection of microorganisms are mainly contributed by holes, and the electrons are mostly wasted [18]. Recently, the multifunctional PEC process has been developed: the holes are utilized for sewage treatment, and simultaneously, electrons are separated for H2 evolution [19,20]. As H2, which can be used as green energy, is produced as a byproduct in this system, it can significantly offset the sewage treatment costs. Therefore, the multifunctional PEC system is expected to achieve high efficiency in sewage treatment with low cost and no secondary pollution.

A well-designed photoelectrode with properties of non-toxicity, excellent PEC performance, and good stability is critical for the multifunctional application [21]. Due to its low cost and high resistance to photocatalytic corrosion, bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) has been widely used as photoanodes in PEC systems for wastewater treatment and water splitting [22,23]. Moreover, the narrow bandgap of 2.4 eV absorbing visible light within 520 nm and a favorable valence band position (around 2.75 eV) to produce strongly oxidizing holes make it a suitable candidate to use in the multifunctional PEC system [24,25]. However, the high charge recombination rate (including bulk and surface recombination) caused by poor charge transfer ability still limits the PEC performance of BiVO4 [26].

The controlling of morphology has been verified as an appropriate method to reduce the bulk recombination of BiVO4 because it can reduce the transmission distance for the charge carriers to the material surface [27]. Kim et al. synthesized a porous BiVO4 photoanode for water splitting using an electrodeposition-annealing process [28]. Kuang et al. optimized the electrolyte for the electrodeposition process and obtained a nanoworm BiVO4 photoanode with doubled photocurrent density compared to the porous one [29]. Based on Kuang’s electrolyte, Huang et al. optimized the applied voltage during the electrodeposition process and attained a bilayered BiOI precursor. The BiVO4 photoanode converted from bilayered BiOI (denoted as BL-BiVO4) showed 1.8 times the photocurrent density of the nanoworm one, mainly contributed by the enhanced charge transfer ability [30].

On the other hand, constructing heterojunction is a suitable strategy to reduce the surface recombination of BiVO4. Not only can it improve the charge transfer property, but it can also change the transfer direction of the charge carriers [31]. MoS2 is a suitable candidate to construct the heterojunction with BL-BiVO4: (1) MoS2 possesses high electrochemical activity to improve the heterojunction’s PEC performance. (2) It is a p-type semiconductor with proper band positions to form a p-n junction with BL-BiVO4, thereby reducing charge recombination. (3) The properties of outstanding stability, non-toxicity, and low-cost make it a promising material to apply in sewage treatment [32,33]. Zheng et al. and Pan et al. synthesized the nanoporous structure MoS2/BiVO4 photoanodes by different strategies to degrade bisphenol A and split water, respectively [17,34]. However, the PEC activities of the photoanodes were far from satisfactory because of the weak charge transmission property of nanoporous BiVO4. Therefore, BL-BiVO4 is introduced to replace the nanoporous BiVO4, forming the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode. By reducing bulk and surface recombination, the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode is expected to perform very well in the multifunctional PEC system.

Herein, a PEC system is developed to simultaneously handle multiple functions — PPCPs degradation, E. coli disinfection, and H2 evolution — through the in-situ activation of chloride ions (Cl−) in sewage. An optimized MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode was synthesized especially for this PEC system. The synthesis process, optimization, and characterization are thoroughly investigated. The mechanisms of chloride activation for promoting PEC reactions, the degradation pathways of the chosen PPCPs, the effects of some main factors on the PEC reactions, and the reusability and stability of the photoanode are also comprehensively studied. This study aims to provide an environmentally friendly and highly efficient sewage treatment technology for pollutants degradation and E. coli disinfection, and to produce green energy (H2) as a high-value byproduct.

Bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3·5H2O), sodium iodide (NaI), potassium iodide (KI), sodium chloride (NaCl), sodium nitrate (NaNO3), calcium chloride dihydrate (CaCl2·2H2O), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and p-benzoquinone used in this study were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH4)2MoS4), vanadyl acetylacetonate (VO(acac)2), and Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) were purchased from Aladdin. Methanol (CH3OH), nitric acid (HNO3), and chloride acid (HCl) were obtained from Merck. Suwannee River natural organic matter (NOM, 2R101 N) was purchased from the international humic substances society. All chemicals were used without purification. Indium tin oxide coated glass (ITO, 30 × 20 × 1.0 mm), purchased from Kaivo (Zhuhai, China), was applied as substrate; all materials were cleaned with deionized water, ethanol, and ultrasound equipment for 20 min before use.

The BiVO4 photoanodes with different morphology were obtained via the optimization of electrolytes and applied voltages during the electrodeposition-annealing processes. The electrodeposition process was conducted in a CorrTest electrochemical workstation (Correct Instruments) with a three-electrode system (working electrode: ITO, reference electrode: Ag/AgCl electrode, counter electrode: Pt foil). The electrolyte for nanoporous BiVO4 (P-BiVO4) preparation was a mixing solution (pH = 1.7, adjusted by HNO3) of 20 mL 0.23 M p-benzoquinone ethanol solution, and 50 mL of 0.4 M KI and 0.04 M Bi(NO3)3 aqueous solution [28]. The BiOI precursor (P-BiOI) of P-BiVO4 was obtained after 5 min of electrodeposition at -0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl using ITO as the working electrolyte. The as-prepared P-BiOI was coated with 0.1 mL of 0.2 M VO(acac)2 DMSO solution before annealing at 420 °C for 2 h. Finally, the as-prepared P-BiVO4 was rinsed using a 1 M NaOH solution to remove excess V2O5.

For the preparation of the BiOI precursor with smaller nanosheets, the electrolyte (pH = 1.2, adjust by HNO3) was composed of 20 mL of 0.3 M p-benzoquinone ethanol solution, and 50 mL of 0.4 M NaI and 7.5 mM Bi(NO3)3 aqueous solution. The smaller size, single-layer BiOI nanosheet (SL-BiOI) was synthesized by 15 min of electrodeposition at -0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl, while bilayered BiOI (BL-BiOI) was obtained by altering the applied potential to 0.01 vs. Ag/AgCl for the same electrodeposition time [29,30]. After being annealed using the same process as P-BiVO4, SL-BiVO4 and BL-BiVO4 were formed from the SL-BiOI and BL-BiOI precursors, respectively.

A chemical bath method was adopted to coat MoS2 onto the BiVO4 photoanodes [35]. The above BiVO4 photoanodes were immersed sequentially in 20 mL of the 0.05 M (NH4)2MoS4 solution for 1 min and then rinsed using deionized water. The immersion process was repeated three times. Afterward, the samples were calcined in a tube furnace at 400 °C for 1 h in an Ar atmosphere. The composite photoanodes were labeled MoS2@P-BiVO4, MoS2@SL-BiVO4, and MoS2@BL-BiVO4, respectively.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-6390) was used to characterize the photoanodes' surface morphology. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the photoanodes were studied in the 2θ range of 10° to 70° using a Philips PW1830 X-ray diffractometer to investigate the crystal structures. The surface chemistry of each photoanode was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5600, USA) using C1s peak (locates at 285.0 eV) as reference. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were investigated by a fluorescence spectrophotometer (F-4500, Hitachi) with an excitation wavelength of 325 nm to analyze the photoanodes’ charge recombination. The functional groups of the photoanode after the recycling tests were studied via a Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometry. A high-performance UV–vis-NIR spectrometer (Lambda 950, USA) with BaSO4 as reflectance standard was applied to investigate the photoanodes' light absorption ability and bandgap. The light-absorption spectra-based Tauc equations were used to determine the bandgap energy of the BL-BiVO4 and MoS2 photoanodes:

Where α is an absorption coefficient, v is the frequency of light, h is Planck’s constant, A is a proportionality constant, and Eg represents bandgap. BL-BiVO4 is a direct bandgap semiconductor and uses Eq. (1) to calculate its bandgap energy, while MoS2 is an indirect bandgap semiconductor and uses Eq. (2). Their bandgap energy was determined by drawing the tangent where the reverse-extension curve intersects with the x-axis, where hv is the x-axis and (αhv)2 or (αhv)1/2 is the y-axis.

Photoelectrochemical (PEC) characterizations were carried out by the above electrochemical workstation with the prepared photoanodes as the working electrode. A 300 W Xenon lamp source (PLS-SXE300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight) with a UV cut-off filter (λ ≥ 420 nm) was used to provide visible-light. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and I-t curves were analyzed using the sewage as the electrolyte to study the photoelectrochemical performance of the synthesized photoanodes. The EIS curves were studied at open potential with a frequency of 10−1-105 Hz under visible-light illumination. The Mott-Schottky plots of MoS2 and BL-BiVO4 were investigated in dark conditions with a frequency of 10 Hz using 0.01 M K3[Fe(CN)6] solution (pH 6.9) as electrolyte. The following equation was used to transform Ag/AgCl reference electrode to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE):
(3)
E
( R H E ) = E ( A g / A g C l ) + 0.0591 p H + 0.197
Where E(Ag/AgCl) is potential vs. Ag/AgCl, E (RHE) is potential vs. RHE, and pH is 6.9 (pH of the K3[Fe(CN)6] electrolyte).

Figure S1a (supplementary information) shows the experimental setup, including a 300 W Xenon lamp, a magnetic stirrer, a single-chamber PEC cell, and the electrochemical workstation. Figure S1b shows details of the PEC cell, consisting of a quartz window, two ports for H2 collection and sewage sampling, and the three electrodes system. Three typical PPCPs — benzophenone-3 (BZP), ibuprofen (IBU), and carbamazepine (CBZ) — were used as target pollutants (Table S2 shows the molecular structures). Secondary treated sewage (before disinfection) was collected from a wastewater treatment plant in Hong Kong (Table S3 shows the sewage properties). The initial density of E. coli in the sewage sample was 13,200 ± 200 (4.12-log) CFU/100 mL. A typical 80-mL sewage sample supplemented with 2 ppm BZP was applied as the electrolyte under visible light illumination, and the applied voltage was 1.0 vs. Ag/AgCl, unless indicated otherwise. For comparison, the electrocatalysis reaction and the photocatalytic reaction were conducted without illumination and applied voltage, respectively. All reactions were performed in triplicate.

A UPLC (Agilent) was used to detect the concentrations of the target pollutants. The mobile phase consisted of an H3PO4 solution (pH 2) and methanol (20:80, v/v %, 1 mL/min). The intermediates of the pollutants were analyzed by an LC–MS (Agilent) using the same mobile phase. The production of hydrogen gas (H2) was measured by gas chromatography (GC) with oven and detector temperatures of 60 and 200 °C, respectively. The degradation efficiency analysis of the pollutants and Faraday efficiency calculations of the H2 evolution are described in Text S1 (supplementary information). The E. coli densities of the sewage before and after PEC treatment was determined using the Membrane Filter Technique [3]. Reactive species scavenging experiments and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were conducted to analyze the reactive species for sewage treatment, as described in Text S2. The effects of the sewage components (natural organic matters (NOM), suspension solids (SS), and inorganic ions) on the PEC reactions were investigated in NaCl electrolyte (with Cl− concentration of 420 mg/L) by imitating the sewage components individually. Details of the experiments are described in Text S3.

SEM images were used to observe the morphology of the prepared photoanodes. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the P-BiOI showed a nanosheet structure with a large space between each flake, which limited the growth of the BiVO4 grains during the annealing process, resulting in the formation of the nanoporous structure [28]. By decreasing the electrolyte’s Bi3+ concentration, the nanosheets in SL-BiOI overlapped each other (Fig. 1b). With the applied voltage further optimized, evenly packed, bilayered nanosheets with the smallest size were formed in BL-BiOI (Fig. 1c). The P-BiVO4 showed a nanoporous structure with a large space between particles, which impeded electrons' transfer towards the ITO substrate (Fig. 1d) [29]. SL-BiVO4 exhibited an intimate package, which was reported to better support charge transfer (Fig. 1e) [29]. As shown in Fig. 1f, the BL-BiVO4, converted from the bilayered BiOI, was composed of particle units with the highest density packing among three BiVO4, which significantly reduced the transmission distance for the internally generated charge carriers to the material’s surface, thereby inhibiting bulk recombination [27]. MoS2@P-BiVO4 retained a similar nanoporous structure as P-BiVO4 because MoS2 adhered thoroughly onto the surface of the P-BiVO4 particles (Fig. 1g). As shown in Fig. 1h&i, as the closely packed BiVO4 particles limited the space for MoS2’s growth, the MoS2 particles evenly coated the top of the SL-BiVO4 and BL-BiVO4 photoanodes.

The Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) spectrum of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 confirmed the co-existence of Bi, Mo, V, S, and O elements, and MoS2 accounted for approximately 2% of the total weight (Figure S2). As shown in the elemental mapping images of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 (Figure S3), all the relative elements were distributed evenly within the area, with Mo and S showing much lower density than the other elements. Figure S4 shows the TEM images of P-BiVO4, SL-BiVO4, BL-BiVO4, and MoS2@BL-BiVO4. P-BiVO4 had an irregular structure with holes inside, thereby forming the porous structure on the FTO substrate (Figure S4a). SL-BiVO4 nanoparticles showed an ellipsoid structure (Figure S4b), while the particles were found to present a sphere structure in BL-BiVO4 (Figure S4c). As shown in Figure S4d, the MoS2 nanoparticles with sizes around 10 nm were evenly coated on the BL-BiVO4’s surface. The intimate contact of these two semiconductors favored the charge transfer of the heterojunction.

The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were used to analyze the photoanodes' crystal structure. In Fig. 2 a, all pristine BiVO4 shared similar XRD spectra with a dominant crystal plane (121) located at 28.9°, determining their monoclinic structure [36]. For the composite photoanodes, peaks at 13.9° corresponding to the (002) crystal plane of MoS2 with low intensity can be observed [35]. The chemical compositions of the photoanodes were investigated via XPS spectra. In Fig. 2b, the survey spectrum of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 confirmed the co-existence of Bi, V, O, Mo, and S, while Mo and S were absent in BL-BiVO4. The peaks located at 159.2 eV (Bi 4f7/2) and 164.5 eV (Bi 4f5/2) with an energy gap of 5.3 eV are typical characteristics of Bi3+ (Fig. 2c). Owing to the low loading of the MoS2, the S peaks located at 161.5 eV (2p3/2) and 162.1 eV (2p1/2) show a low intensity. As shown in Fig. 2d, four Mo 3d peaks corresponding to Mo (+4) 3d3/2 (232.3 eV), Mo (+4) 3d5/2 (228.8 eV), Mo (+6) 3d3/2 (235.8 eV), and Mo (+6) 3d3/2 (233.0 eV) can be observed [37]. The incomplete decomposition of (NH4)2MoS4 during the calcination led to the detection of Mo+6 3d3/2 [33]. In Fig. 2e, there are two types of O elements in the MoS2@BL-BiVO4: O2− (530.1 eV) in the BiVO4 crystal lattice and hydroxyl groups (532.2 eV) on the material surface [38]. In Fig. 2f, the peaks at 524.75 eV (V 2p1/2) and 525.01 eV (V 2p3/2) corresponded to V5+ species, while the peaks at 524.75 eV and 525.01 eV were assigned as V 2p1/2 and V 2p3/2 of V4+ [38]. The XPS and XRD spectra further confirmed the co-existence of the well-crystallized BiVO4 and MoS2 in the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode.

Fig. 3 a shows the light absorption spectra of the photoanodes. All pristine BiVO4 showed overlapped light absorption spectra. Owing to the excellent light absorption ability of MoS2, the MoS2@BiVO4 photoanodes showed a slightly higher absorption intensity than pristine BiVO4 in the whole detected region. As shown in Figure S5, the bandgaps of BL-BiVO4 and MoS2 were determined to be 2.40 and 1.73 eV using equations 1&2. In Figure S6, the Mott-Schottky plots revealed that BL-BiVO4 was an n-type semiconductor with a flat band potential of -0.29 eV vs. Ag/AgCl, and MoS2 was a p-type semiconductor with a flat band potential of 1.08 eV vs. Ag/AgCl. The flat band potentials of BL-BiVO4 and MoS2 were further calculated to be 0.32 eV vs. RHE and 1.68 eV vs. RHE using Eq. 3. As the conduction band potential of an n-type semiconductor and the valence band potential of a p-type semiconductor was similar to the flat band potentials, the conduction band position of BL-BiVO4 and the valence band position of MoS2 were determined to be 0.32 eV vs. RHE and 1.68 eV vs. RHE, respectively [33]. Combining the bandgaps of the two semiconductors, the valence band position of BL-BiVO4 and the conduction band position of MoS2 were calculated to be 2.72 eV vs. RHE and -0.05 eV vs. RHE. A type II band alignment p-n junction was formed in the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode, which significantly reduced surface recombination (Fig. 3b): first, the p-n junction formed an internal electrostatic field on the interface between MoS2 and BL-BiVO4 where electrons in BL-BiVO4 and holes in MoS2 were depleted, forcing electrons to transfer and delaying charge recombination; second, the alterant direction of charge transfer also inhibited the recombination of holes and electrons [39,40].

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out under visible-light illumination, in which a smaller radius indicates less resistance against charge transfer (Fig. 3c). Since the high-density packing structure can better support charge transfer, the BL-BiVO4 exhibited the smallest resistance among all pristine BiVO4. All MoS2@BiVO4 photoanodes showed lower resistance than pristine BiVO4, and among them, MoS2@BL-BiVO4 exhibited the lowest, indicating that the loading of MoS2 can further improve the charge transfer ability of the materials. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were analyzed to reveal the recombination of charge carriers (Fig. 3d). An emission band in the region of 480−590 nm corresponding to the band-band PL phenomenon of BiVO4 was present in all spectra, while no peak was produced from MoS2 [41]. The lowest charge recombination among the pristine BiVO4 was BL-BiVO4, where the smallest BiVO4 particles shortened the internal distance for charge transfer, hence reducing bulk recombination. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 displayed the least amount of charge recombination, indicating that more electrons and holes can be released by this photoanode for the PEC reactions.

The photoanodes' PEC performances were studied by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and I-t curves using sewage as the electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 3e, all photoanodes showed continuously increasing photocurrent densities with the applied voltage, of which the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 showed the fastest increasing rate. The improved PEC performance of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 was mainly attributed to the reduced charge recombination. Moreover, the onset potential of the BiVO4 photoanodes decreases from 0.25 V to 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl by coating MoS2, which was attributed to MoS2’s negative conduction band position as well its excellent electrochemical property [35]. As a result, less energy was needed to drive the PEC process. As shown in Fig. 3f, all photoanodes showed stable and repeatable photocurrent densities. The photocurrent densities were 0.27, 0.52, and 0.74 mA/cm2 for P-BiVO4, SL-BiVO4, and BL-BiVO4 at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which increased to 1.06, 1.50, and 2.21 mA/cm2 for the corresponding MoS2@BiVO4 photoanodes. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode showed the highest photocurrent density, as 8.1 times of P-BiVO4 and 2.9 times of BL-BiVO4, indicating that the PEC performance of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 was significantly improved via the strategies of reducing bulk and surface recombination.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The simultaneous BZP degradation, E. coli disinfection, and H2 evolution in sewage
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 4 a-c shows the simultaneous BZP degradation, E. coli disinfection, and H2 evolution by different systems using MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode in real sewage. Photolysis and electrolysis were set as control experiments. In 30 min, only 10.1 % and 14.1 % of BZP were removed by electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, while the PEC system achieved complete degradation (Fig. 4a). As shown in Table 1 , the degradation efficiency of BZP in real sewage obtained in this study was higher than other AOPs in deionized (DI) water, offering promising practicality. As shown in Figure S7, the BZP degradation rate constant of the PEC system was 0.1088 min−1, 30 times that of electrocatalysis (0.0036 min−1), and 21 times that of photocatalysis (0.0051 min−1), indicating the combination of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis achieved a synergistic effect. Likewise, photocatalysis and electrocatalysis could hardly disinfect E. coli in sewage, while the PEC system thoroughly inactivated the E. coli (Fig. 4b).

As shown in Fig. 4c, H2 production was negligible in electrolysis and photocatalysis: the unfavorable conduction band of BiVO4 and low loading content of MoS2 made H2 insignificant in photocatalysis, while the low applied voltage cannot split water in electrocatalysis. The H2 evolution was 89.32 μmol in 30 min by the PEC system, comparable to the reported H2 evolution processes in the specified electrolytes by BiVO4-based photoanodes (Table 2 ). Although the PEC system achieved significant H2 evolution, the Pt cathode is not suitable for practical application due to its high cost. Therefore, the cathodes should be further developed to balance the cost of sewage treatment better. Alternatively, the transition-metal-based electrodes have been reported as low-cost cathodes with comparable performance as Pt for H2 evolution, which can be a proper candidate [51]. The source for H2 evolution was also investigated. As shown in Figure S8, no H2 can be generated using the electrons scavenger, demonstrating that H2 production was driven by elections’ reduction power. In comparison, the H2 generation was slightly promoted when eliminating holes from the PEC system, attributed to the adding of holes scavenger can reduce charge recombination to separate more electrons for H2 evolution.

Fig. 4d compares the PEC degradation of BZP by different photoanodes at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The BZP degradation efficiencies were 36.4 %, 48.8 %, and 57.4 % for P-BiVO4, SL-BiVO4, and BL-BiVO4. After being coated with MoS2, the figures increased to 77.4 %, 87.6 %, and 100 % for MoS2@P-BiVO4, MoS2@SL-BiVO4, and MoS2@BL-BiVO4. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 showed the highest BZP degradation rate constant of 0.1088 min−1, 7.2 times that of P-BiVO4 (0.0151 min−1), indicating significantly accelerated BZP degradation was achieved by reducing both surface and bulk recombination (Figure S9a). As shown in Fig. 4e, the sewage samples treated by pristine BiVO4 photoanodes cannot meet the acceptable E. coli discharge limit for the tertiary treatment plant (1500 CFU/100 mL), while the densities of E. coli were reduced to less than 500 CFU/100 mL (2.70-log CFU/100 mL) in the sewage samples treated by the MoS2@BiVO4 photoanodes. As shown in Fig. 4f, the H2 evolution values were 12.29 and 89.32 μmol in 30 min for P-BiVO4 and MoS2@BL-BiVO4, and a 6.3-time increase of H2 evolution was obtained by MoS2@BL-BiVO4, which was mainly due to the promoted charge separation (Figure S9b) via optimizing the photoanode.

Due to its highly positive valence band, BL-BiVO4 can produce holes with a strong oxidation ability to generate
OH (
OH/H2O ∼2.38 eV) under visible-light illumination. As the concentration of chloride ions in the sewage (420.92 ± 2.14 mg/L) is very high, the chemical reactions arising from the PEC system with MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode are (at pH 7.2) [52]:

The optimization of the photoanodes dramatically reduces the charge recombination (Eq. (2)), so most of the holes and electrons can be used respectively for sewage treatment and H2 evolution. Moreover, the chloride ions can react with holes to produce chloride-based radicals for sewage treatment and reduce charge recombination to increase the H2 evolution. According to the above equations, h+, ∙

Cl (i.e., 2.4 V),
OH (i.e., 2.8 V) and
ClO (i.e., 1.8 V) are oxidants, which may contribute to the simultaneous BZP degradation and E. coli disinfection.

Reactive species scavenging experiments were conducted to study the contribution of the above active species in BZP degradation and E. coli disinfection. Benzoquinone (BQ) can eliminate ∙

O 2 −
only contributed 5.8 % of the BZP degradation and 2.1 % E. coli disinfection. EtOH (50 mM) restricted 82.2 % BZP degradation and 94.4 % of E. coli disinfection, and the elimination of

Cl,

Cl contributed the most.

EPR measurements were performed to confirm the existence of
Cl,
ClO, and
OH in the PEC reactions. As shown in Fig. 5c, there was no signal in dark condition using MoS2@BL-BiVO4 as the working electrode; only
OH could be detected in DI water under visible-light illumination.
Cl,
ClO, and
OH could be detected in sewage under visible-light illumination regardless of whether BL-BiVO4 or MoS2@BL-BiVO4 was used, verifying the generation of these species during the PEC reactions. The peak intensities of these species in the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 case were much stronger than in the BL-BiVO4 case, indicating that MoS2@BL-BiVO4 can produce more of those species to accelerate the sewage treatment process.

Based on the above results and discussion, the whole process of the PEC reaction in sewage using the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode is illustrated in Fig. 5d. Upon visible-light illumination, the charge carriers produced by MoS2@BL-BiVO4 were rapidly separated via electrostatic forces from the p-n junction. Electrons were transferred to the Pt counter electrode under the applied bias, while holes accumulated on the photoanode surface. The strongly-oxidizing holes generated by BL-BiVO4 can initiate a series of chemical reactions: the H2O and OH− were oxidized to become
OH; the Cl− was activated to become
Cl and further converts into
ClO. As the activation of chloride consumed most holes, charge recombination was further impeded, and more electrons can transfer to the counter electrode. At the counter electrode, most electrons were used for H2 evolution, while a few of the electrons reacted with dissolved oxygen to produce ∙
O 2 −
. All the above active species contributed to the PPCPs degradation and E. coli disinfection.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Factors that influence the PEC reactions

ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 6 a shows how the initial electrolyte’s pH influenced BZP degradation by MoS2@BL-BiVO4. BZP can be thoroughly degraded at pH 5.0 and pH 7.2 in 30 min, and the degradation efficiency was impeded in both acid and alkaline conditions. In figure S10, the degradation rate constants of BZP follow the order: pH 5 > pH 7.2 > pH 3 > pH 9 > pH 11, indicating that weak acid and neutral conditions benefited the BZP degradation. Similarly, the PEC system showed higher efficiency at pH 5.0 and pH 7.2 for E. coli disinfection and lower efficiency in acid and alkaline conditions (Fig. 6b). As shown in Figure S11, the zero charge point (pHpzc) of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 was at pH 4.5, and the surface charge of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 was positive at pH 3, which reduced the surface adsorption of BZP and E. coli, slowing down the sewage treatment [54]. In alkaline conditions, O2 evolution was the predominant reaction in the PEC system, which consumed a great number of holes, thereby reducing the efficiency of the sewage treatment [52]. On the other hand, weak acid and neutral conditions favored the activation of Cl− to generate more chloride-based radicals, promoting BZP degradation and E. coli disinfection [17]. As wastewater generally has pH 5 – 8, the excellent performance of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 in weak acid and neutral conditions ensures its practicality.

The effects of different applied voltages on the PEC reactions were also investigated. As shown in Fig. 6c, the charge carriers' high recombination rate at low applied voltages led to low BZP degradation efficiency: 26.2 % and 71.2 % of the BZP was degraded in 30 min at 0 V and 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl, respectively. At higher voltages, BZP was completely removed in 30 min at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl and 25 min at 1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. As shown in Figure S12a, the degradation rate constants of the BZP increased with applied voltages. The sewage treated at 0 V and 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl could not meet the E. coli discharge standard for tertiary treatment plants (Fig. 6d). In comparison, E. coli was thoroughly inactivated at 1.0 V and 1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. As shown in Fig. 6e, the positive conduction band of BiVO4 (0.32 V vs. RHE) and the low loading content of MoS2 made H2 evolution negligible at 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Higher applied voltages can better force charge separation (Figure S12b), resulting in the value of H2 evolution raised from 30.81 μmol at 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl to 142.26 μmol at 1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl in 30 min.

Figure S13 shows the relationship among applied voltage, BZP degradation rate constant, and H2 evolution. In ideal conditions, both BZP degradation rate constants and H2 evolution should increase linearly with the voltage applied [20,55]. As some components in the sewage (SS, NOM, etc.) may consume active species and electrons, both sewage treatment and H2 production were greatly impeded at low applied voltages [22]. At high applied voltages, a significant number of charge carriers was generated, as these components can only consume a small part of charge carriers, so the effects were negligible. TOC removal during PEC reactions at different voltages was also investigated (Fig. 6f). The initial concentration of TOC in the sewage was around 7.3 mg/L (spiked with 2 ppm BZP). Although only 26.2 % of the BZP was degraded in 30 min at 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl, 3.81 mg/L of the TOC (52.1 %) was removed, which was attributed to the fact that NOM was more easily mineralized than BZP. 5.47 and 7.03 mg/L of TOC were removed at 0.5 V and 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl, and it could be completely removed at 1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl, indicating that the mineralization process accelerated with the applied voltage.

IBU and CBZ were also applied as target pollutants in both NaCl electrolyte (with Cl− concentration of 420 mg/L) and sewage to evaluate the proposed PEC system's extensive applicability. Fig. 7 a shows that complete degradation of IBU and BZP by MoS2@BL-BiVO4 in NaCl electrolyte was achieved in 15 min, while CBZ was wholly degraded in 20 min. The molecular structure of CBZ is more complicated than IBU and BZP (Table S2), resulting in a longer time being required for complete degradation. Fig. 8 shows the degradation pathways of the chosen PPCPs. Hydroxylation was found to initiate the degradation processes for all three PPCPs because of the strongly oxidizing ability of
OH. Driven by the other reactive species, the intermediates can be further degraded into small molecule organics and finally mineralized through demethylation, CC bond cleavage, and benzene ring opening. These degradation routes are consistent with previous studies [19,56–58]. In sewage, the times for complete degradation of IBU, BZP, and CBZ were 25 min, 30 min, and 45 min, respectively. These results confirmed that the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode is a proper candidate for PEC degradation of various PPCPs.

As reported in previous studies, some sewage components, including NOM, SS, and inorganic ions, may interfere with the materials or reactive species, thereby affecting the PEC performance [22,59]. The above components were mimicked individually in the NaCl electrolyte in order to study their effects on PEC degradation of BZP coupled with H2 evolution. As shown in Fig. 7b, SS and NOM impeded the BZP degradation to different extents (Figure S14a, degradation rate constants of BZP: 0.2584 min−1 for NaCl solution, 0.1933 and 0.1504 min−1 for adding SS and NOM, respectively), while inorganic ions slightly promoted BZP degradation (degradation rate constant: 0.2791 min−1). As shown in Fig. 7c, H2 evolution in the NaCl solution was 141.16 μmol in 30 min, which was 51.84 μmol more than that in the sewage (89.32 μmol). Similar to BZP degradation, H2 evolution was decreased when adding SS and NOM, while inorganic ions increased the H2 generation. The dashed lines show the theoretical evolution of H2 in the NaCl solution and sewage as calculated from the recorded photocurrents (Figure S14b), where the Faraday efficiency was 85.4 % for the NaCl solution and 75.9 % for the sewage.

During the PEC reactions, both SS and NOM can be adsorbed onto the surface of the photoanode to block the separation of the charge carriers and mask the active sites [22]. In addition, they can compete for reactive species with BZP to significantly slow down the degradation process and work as electrons acceptors to reduce H2 evolution [59]. On the contrary, the electrolyte's conductivity was increased by adding inorganic ions (Table S4), which can better support the separation of charge carriers (Figure S14b), thereby promoting both BZP degradation and H2 evolution. As to the Faraday efficiency, the chloride-based radicals (
Cl and
ClO) in the NaCl solution could react with electrons to reduce the Faraday efficiency of the H2 evolution (Eq. 13 and 14) [60]. In the sewage, the lower Faraday efficiency for H2 evolution was caused by interference from the NOM, SS, and chloride-based radicals.

As discussed above, NOM was the dominant component negatively affecting both BZP degradation and H2 evolution. Fluorescence EEM measurements were made to investigate how NOM affected the PEC reactions. Fig. 7d shows the EEM image of sewage spiked with 2 ppm BZP before treatment. Three signals corresponding to humic acid-like substances (excitation (Ex) 300–370 nm, emission (Em) 370–500 nm, letter A), fulvic acid-like substances (Ex 200–250 nm, Em 320–520 nm, letter B), and aromatic proteins (Ex 230–400 nm, Em 300–550 nm, letter C) can be observed [61]. Treated by the PEC system (Fig. 7e-g), the signals of humic acid-like and fulvic acid-like substances disappeared after 20 min of treatment (Fig. 7f), indicating that they were efficiently degraded by the PEC reactions. The aromatic proteins accounted for a high proportion of NOM in the sewage and were more difficult to be degraded, and remained detectable after 30 min of PEC treatment (Fig. 7g). On the other hand, cellular proteins and nuclear acids were leaked into the sewage by the inactivated bacteria during the PEC reactions, which also increased the concentration of aromatic proteins [62]. These results are consistent with the TOC removal profiles, where almost all of the NOM was mineralized in 30 min. In addition, the incident light signal (Ex 250–550 nm, Em 250–550 nm) became stronger with treated time because the concentration of the fluorescent absorbers was reduced during the PEC reactions. The above results demonstrated that the main components of NOM that competed for active species with BZP and affected H2 evolution were the humic acid-like and fulvic acid-like substances. The signals corresponding to all of the above components remained after 30 min of photocatalytic (Fig. 7h) and electrocatalytic (Fig. 7i) treatments, indicating that the PEC system was more advanced in sewage treatment.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Reusability and stability of MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode
ce:section.ce:para: Cycling tests were conducted in both the NaCl solution and sewage to study the stability and reusability of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode. Fig. 9 a shows that 97.69 % BZP was degraded in the NaCl solution in the 5th cycle, but the degradation rate of BZP dropped to 86.15 % in the 5th cycle in the real sewage. Moreover, only a 10.05 % decrease of H2 production was detected in the NaCl solution after five cycles, while a 22.76 % reduction was observed in the real sewage (Fig. 9b). Fig. 9c shows that the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode had outstanding stability for E. coli disinfection — at least 99 % of the E. coli was disinfected over the five cycles. The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode was less stable in sewage than in the NaCl solution. As shown in Figure S15, the XRD patterns indicate that the crystal structure of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanodes after the recycling tests (regardless in the NaCl solution or sewage) remained the same as the fresh sample. As shown in the FTIR spectra (Fig. 9d), the tested photoanode in sewage showed several new peaks within the 1300−1750 cm−1 wavelength range compared with the photoanode applied in the NaCl solution, and was attributed to the adsorption of NOM on the photoanode’s surface [63]. As discussed above, the NOM on the photoanode's surface can obstruct charge separation and mask the active sites. As shown in Table S5, the XPS analysis showed that the photoanode after cycling test in sewage had a much higher C weight percentage than the fresh photoanode and the one applied in NaCl solution, further confirming the adsorption of NOM on the photoanode's surface. Therefore, the reduced stability and reusability of the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode in sewage were mainly due to the adsorption of NOM.

In this study, a PEC system was developed to simultaneously degrade PPCPs, disinfect E. coli, and produce H2 in sewage using a MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode. The main findings of this study are listed as follows:
•
By controlling the morphology of BiVO4 and coating it with MoS2, charge recombination was significantly reduced, resulting in improved PEC performance: the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode obtained the highest photocurrent density of 2.21 mA/cm2 at 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl in sewage, 8.1 times that of P-BiVO4.
•
In sewage, the MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode completely degraded 2 ppm BZP and disinfected E. coli in the PEC system in 30 min and simultaneously produced 89.32 μmol of H2 as a byproduct. The combination of PC and EC showed a synergistic effect. The activation of chloride ions not only produced
Cl and
ClO for sewage treatment, but also consumed holes to promote H2 evolution.
•
The best PEC BZP degradation efficiency was attained in weak acids and neutral pH; the high applied voltage can promote the PEC reactions and mineralization process; NOM was the sewage component that impeded the PEC reactions the most.
•
The MoS2@BL-BiVO4 photoanode also showed good reusability and stability, ensuring its practicality.
Overall, based on its high efficiency in treating sewage, coupled with good H2 evolution and stability, this multifunctional PEC system has shown great practicality.
